body.name: The Lake Pavilion : A sweeping historical novel set in British India of the 1930s and wartime England. (The Oriental Lake Collection)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I love reading books that take place in India. There is so much about this beautiful country that I was never taught in school . This story peeked my interest right from the start and even though I was able to figure out some of the plot early on, I continued to read on enjoying each chapter.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I discovered Ann Bennett not too long ago and have since read all her books. Her books are always enjoyable and she is able to paint an excellent picture. This book had a great sense of mystery to it. Ann Bennett’s book tend to go over multiple time frames. This one took up 3 different time frames. My favourite bits are always the timeframes from the 30/40s I think this book would have been just as successful if it had told just the story of Amelia. I could have easily read more and more of Amelia’s story. For Kate’s story o enjoyed guessing what her and Joan could have possibly done, but also could have done without her part. If I saw it was a chapter to do with Amelia I would always keep reading, if it was a chapter about Kate that was my signal to go to bed. With that said I am always looking forward to more books by Ann Bennett and cannot wait for the next

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Interesting book set in England and India
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed this book. It was well written and it was about a girls great aunt what happened to her during 1936-1940 In India. Also it was about her niece Kate had inherited her great aunts cottage and finding out what exactly happened during during those years before her aunt came back to England. As well as finding herself after thinking for many years exactly what happened the summer of 1940 in England. The story goes back-and-forth between 1930’s and 1970. I recommend this book to anyone who enjoys reading fiction books based on historical facts.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars British Indian set during the 30s & 40s
reviews.reviewText: This historical novel set in Colonial India 1930-1940 is colorful and spectacular in scene. I do not think it would have suited me as I am too independent in thought and action to ever fit I into that stilted society even the UK of today doesn’t sit well with me.Still I love the food and customs on Indian people.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2021
reviews.reviewText: Though I generally find parallel historical narratives annoying, I've always liked historical novels set in India, so I gave this one a try. This one was nicely written, moderately engaging, and somewhat suspenseful. But it could have used a good copy editor. It had numerous grammatical errors, particularly in verb forms, which--as a retired editor--I found distracting.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great read that kept my attention
reviews.reviewText: This author writes excellently! Nothing slow in the story. The time period moves around but in a way that works. Nothing is confusing in the story. You feel like you know the characters. Each one is valuable to the story. Not so many characters that could be confusing. I’m looking to read another one of her books as I enjoy the way she writes. Throughout the story there is a mystery that reveals itself in the end; it surprised me how it ended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
reviews.reviewText: My grandmother spent some time in India as a small child when her family was in the British Army.She told us tales from being there. I enjoyed the knowledge that the author had of life in India as a British subject prior to India's Independence. Such a shame how they lorded it over those people. Great story!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2021
reviews.reviewText: This was my first book that I read by Ann Bennett. I thoroughly enjoyed it from beginning to end. The characters were well presented, and the plot captivating. Such distaste I had for Reginald! He was portrayed as an evil man from the get go. I was pleased with the ending, and how the choices of the past, helped to correct possible ill outcomes for Joan and Kate's futures.
I couldn’t put it down. The time changes were smooth and natural. The characters engaged the reader. The plot was well written and I never saw the ending coming. Bravo.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 2, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This tells the tale of Kate who inherits a big house from her Great Aunt Amelia. While sorting out the house Kate reveals lots of secrets and lies.I didn't want this book to end. It is so well written and like all of AB books it drew me in. I loved all the characters in it.5 star read.

This is the first novel I have read by Ann Bennett and I must say I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of it. Good story, good plot lines, engaging and believable characters, all the ingredients of a great story. Have downloaded the follow-up The Lake Palace and looking forward to reading that one.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 9, 2023
reviews.reviewText: It was a great read. Totally Unputadownable

The book is full of suspense to solve two mysteries, that are connected through the main protagonists - Kate and her great aunt Amelia - and across time and place. The last days of the British Raj is the setting for Amelia's mystery, and a village in England for Kate's. This is a page-turner and historically evocative.
